repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
* Wraps `PyMutex` (in recent Python) and `PyThread_type_lock` (earlier).
* Is usable in a `with` block so has fairly nice syntax.
* Acquiring a lock while holding the GIL shouldn't be able to deadlock (although the inverse isn't true).

This is intended to be an alternative to `cython.critical_section` that avoids the issues that make critical section unintuitive (i.e. the lock can be released inside a section) at the cost that it's easier to write deadlocks.

comment_data.body:
I'm not completely sure this is the right place to do it. But it does seem to work.

It's currently undertested though

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -188,6 +188,23 @@ def with_compiler_directives(self):

+    def find_shared_cy_pymutexes(self, env, include_all_attrs=False, seen_scopes=None):
+        if seen_scopes is None:
+            seen_scopes = set()
+        for entry in env.entries.values():
+            if not (include_all_attrs or entry.defined_in_pxd or entry.visibility == "public" or entry.api):
+                continue
+            entry_subtypes = get_all_subtypes(entry.type)
+            if any(sub_tp is PyrexTypes.cy_pymutex_type for sub_tp in entry_subtypes):
+                return True
+            if hasattr(entry.type, "scope") and entry.type.scope is not None:
+                if entry.type.scope in seen_scopes:
+                    continue
+                seen_scopes.add(entry.type.scope)
+                if self.find_shared_cy_pymutexes(entry.type.scope, include_all_attrs=True, seen_scopes=seen_scopes):
+                    return True
+        return False

comment_data.body: Rather than *always* testing first whether explicit construction/destruction is needed and then doing it, we could just always call `generate_explicit_destruction()` on the type and let the type (hierarchy) decide whether it needs to do something or not.

+class CythonLockStatNode(TryFinallyStatNode):

+    lock_temp = None
+
+    nogil_check = None

comment_data.body: The nogil state seems to be used as a property of nodes. Should we move the `NoGilState` enum class into `Nodes.py` to avoid a dependency on the transforms module?

comment_data.body: Is this worth a `code.put_cppnew(type_name, decl_code)` (names up for debate) to avoid importing `Code.UtilityCode` here? (Besides, we already import `UtilityCode` in `PyrexTypes.py`.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4322,6 +4344,24 @@ def cpp_optional_check_for_null_code(self, cname):
         # only applies to c++ classes that are being declared as std::optional
         return "(%s.has_value())" % cname
 
+    def needs_explicit_construction(self, scope):
+        return scope.is_c_class_scope
+
+    def needs_explicit_destruction(self, scope):
+        return self.needs_explicit_construction(scope)  # same rules
+
+    def generate_explicit_destruction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        code.putln(f"__Pyx_call_destructor({extra_access_code}{entry.cname});")
+
+    def generate_explicit_construction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        from . import Code
+        code.globalstate.use_utility_code(Code.UtilityCode("#include <new>"))
+        if entry.is_cpp_optional:
+            decl_code = self.cpp_optional_declaration_code("")
+        else:
+            decl_code = self.empty_declaration_code()
+        code.putln(f"new((void*)&({extra_access_code}{entry.cname})) {decl_code}();")

@@ -4787,6 +4827,113 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
 
+class CythonLockType(PyrexType):
+    """
+    A C lock type that can be used in with statements
+    (within Cython - it can't be returned to Python) and
+    safely acquired while holding the GIL.
+    """
+    is_cython_lock_type = True
+    has_attributes = True
+    exception_value = None
+
+    scope = None
+
+    @property
+    def declaration_value(self):
+        return f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_DECL"
+
+    def __init__(self, cname_part):
+        self.cname_part = cname_part
+
+        # Create a reference type that we can use in the definitions of acquire and release
+        # to override the general prohibition of assigning anything to this
+        class SpecialAssignableReferenceType(CReferenceType):
+            def assignable_from(self, src_type):
+                return src_type is self.ref_base_type
+        self._special_assignable_reference_type = SpecialAssignableReferenceType(self)
+
+    def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
+            for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):

@@ -4787,6 +4827,113 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
 
+class CythonLockType(PyrexType):
+    """
+    A C lock type that can be used in with statements
+    (within Cython - it can't be returned to Python) and
+    safely acquired while holding the GIL.
+    """
+    is_cython_lock_type = True
+    has_attributes = True
+    exception_value = None
+
+    scope = None
+
+    @property
+    def declaration_value(self):
+        return f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_DECL"
+
+    def __init__(self, cname_part):
+        self.cname_part = cname_part
+
+        # Create a reference type that we can use in the definitions of acquire and release
+        # to override the general prohibition of assigning anything to this
+        class SpecialAssignableReferenceType(CReferenceType):
+            def assignable_from(self, src_type):
+                return src_type is self.ref_base_type
+        self._special_assignable_reference_type = SpecialAssignableReferenceType(self)
+
+    def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
+            for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):
+        if for_display or pyrex:
+            if self.cname_part == "PyThreadTypeLock":
+                return "cython.pythread_type_lock"
+            else:
+                return "cython.pymutex"
+        return f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part} {entity_code}"
+
+    def assignable_from(self, src_type):
+        # cannot be copied.
+        if src_type is self._special_assignable_reference_type:
+            return True
+        return False

comment_data.body: This setup seems a rather large side effect for a simple predicate like `attributes_known()`. I'm not sure if there's a better way, and won't reject this if there's a reason why it's done here, but it seems worth reconsidering it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4787,6 +4827,113 @@ def specialize_here(self, pos, env, template_values=None):
         return template_values[0].resolve()
 
 
+class CythonLockType(PyrexType):
+    """
+    A C lock type that can be used in with statements
+    (within Cython - it can't be returned to Python) and
+    safely acquired while holding the GIL.
+    """
+    is_cython_lock_type = True
+    has_attributes = True
+    exception_value = None
+
+    scope = None
+
+    @property
+    def declaration_value(self):
+        return f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_DECL"
+
+    def __init__(self, cname_part):
+        self.cname_part = cname_part
+
+        # Create a reference type that we can use in the definitions of acquire and release
+        # to override the general prohibition of assigning anything to this
+        class SpecialAssignableReferenceType(CReferenceType):
+            def assignable_from(self, src_type):
+                return src_type is self.ref_base_type
+        self._special_assignable_reference_type = SpecialAssignableReferenceType(self)
+
+    def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
+            for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):
+        if for_display or pyrex:
+            if self.cname_part == "PyThreadTypeLock":
+                return "cython.pythread_type_lock"
+            else:
+                return "cython.pymutex"
+        return f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part} {entity_code}"
+
+    def assignable_from(self, src_type):
+        # cannot be copied.
+        if src_type is self._special_assignable_reference_type:
+            return True
+        return False
+
+    def get_utility_code(self):
+        # It doesn't seem like a good way to associate utility code with a type actually exists
+        # so we just have to do it in as many places as possible.
+        return UtilityCode.load_cached(self.cname_part, "Lock.c")
+
+    def needs_explicit_construction(self, scope):
+        # Where possible we use mutex types that don't require
+        # explicit construction (e.g. PyMutex). However, on older
+        # versions this isn't possible, and we fall back to types
+        # that do need non-static initialization.
+        return True
+
+    def needs_explicit_destruction(self, scope):
+        return True
+
+    def generate_explicit_construction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        code.globalstate.use_utility_code(
+            self.get_utility_code()
+        )
+        code.putln(f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_Init({extra_access_code}{entry.cname});")
+
+    def generate_explicit_destruction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        code.putln(
+            f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_Delete({extra_access_code}{entry.cname});")
+
+    def attributes_known(self):
+        if self.scope is None:
+            from . import Symtab
+
+            self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope(

comment_data.body: If it's really `list_or_subtype`, I'd rather test `isinstance(…, list)` than `BaseType`, which refers to a whole, complex type hierarchy that is not entirely unlikely to change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5576,3 +5726,19 @@ def remove_cv_ref(tp, remove_fakeref=False):
         if tp.is_reference and (not tp.is_fake_reference or remove_fakeref):
             tp = tp.ref_base_type
     return tp
+
+def get_all_subtypes(tp, seen=None):
+    if seen is None:
+        seen = set()
+    if tp in seen:
+        return
+    seen.add(tp)
+    for attr in tp.subtypes:
+        list_or_subtype = getattr(tp, attr)
+        if list_or_subtype:
+            if isinstance(list_or_subtype, BaseType):
+                get_all_subtypes(list_or_subtype, seen)
+            else:
+                for sub_tp in list_or_subtype:
+                    get_all_subtypes(sub_tp, seen)

comment_data.body:
Not sure which is more common, but I see two different ways for spelling this:

If we need to do the same thing for "nogil" and "maybe gil" and something else for "gil", then 0, 1, 2 (as used here) nicely allow a distinction as `if state != 0: do_nogil_stuff()`, and I'd refer to the last state as "maybe nogil" rather than "maybe gil" for better grouping,

If we must do one thing for "nogil" and something else for both "gil" and "maybe gil, then I'd rather use `0` for `nogil` to make the distinction ("nogil" or not) easy and keep the names as they are here.

@@ -370,18 +370,20 @@ def generate_function_definitions(self, env, code):
         self.body.generate_function_definitions(env, code)
 
 
-class HasGilNode(AtomicExprNode):
+class HasNoGilNode(AtomicExprNode):
     """
-    Simple node that evaluates to 0 or 1 depending on whether we're
-    in a nogil context
+    Simple node that evaluates to
+    * 0 if gil
+    * 1 if nogil
+    * 2 if maybe gil

comment_data.body: I'd split this loop into three, and maybe even three different functions. A fast "acquire, done" one that can be inlined in the good case, one for the fast spin, and finally one for the slow spin. That tends to work better for both inlining and branch prediction.
"It's more robust, but you lose robustness." – :-?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,46 @@ We suggest reading the Python documentation to understand how critical sections
   critical section in favour of a critical section based on that object.
 
 On non-freethreading builds ``cython.critical_section`` does nothing - you get the
-same guarantees simply from the fact you hold the GIL.
+same guarantees simply from the fact you hold the GIL.  Our current experience is
+that this provides slightly less thread-safety than you get in freethreading builds
+simply because Python releases the GIL more readily than it releases a critical
+section.
+
+Locks
+-----
+
+Cython provides ``cython.pymutex`` as a more robust lock type.  Unlike
+``cython.critical_section`` this will never release the lock unless you explicitly
+ask it to (at the cost of losing ``critical_section``'s inbuilt robustness against
+deadlocks).

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
On Python 3.13+, ``cython.pymutex`` is just a
`PyMutex <https://docs.python.org/3.13/c-api/init.html#synchronization-primitives>`_
and so is very low-cost.  On earlier versions of Python, it uses the
(undocumented) ``PyThread_type_lock``.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -85,7 +85,46 @@ We suggest reading the Python documentation to understand how critical sections
   critical section in favour of a critical section based on that object.
 
 On non-freethreading builds ``cython.critical_section`` does nothing - you get the
-same guarantees simply from the fact you hold the GIL.
+same guarantees simply from the fact you hold the GIL.  Our current experience is
+that this provides slightly less thread-safety than you get in freethreading builds
+simply because Python releases the GIL more readily than it releases a critical
+section.
+
+Locks
+-----
+
+Cython provides ``cython.pymutex`` as a more robust lock type.  Unlike
+``cython.critical_section`` this will never release the lock unless you explicitly
+ask it to (at the cost of losing ``critical_section``'s inbuilt robustness against
+deadlocks).
+
+``cython.pymutex`` supports two operations: ``acquire`` and ``release``.
+``cython.pymutex`` can also be used in a ``with`` statement::
+
+  cdef cython.pymutex l
+  with l:
+      ...  # perform operations with the lock
+  
+  # or manually
+  l.acquire()
+  ...  # perform operations with the lock
+  l.release()
+
+``acquire`` will avoid deadlocks if the GIL is held (only relevant in 
+non-freethreading versions of Python).  However, you are at risk of deadlock
+if you attempt to acquire the GIL while holding a ``cython.pymutex`` lock.
+Be aware that it is also possible for Cython to acquire the GIL implicitly
+(for example by raising an exception) and this is also a deadlock risk.
+
+On Python 3.13+ ``cython.pymutex`` is just a `PyMutex <https://docs.python.org/3.13/c-api/init.html#synchronization-primitives>`_
+and so is very low-cost. On earlier versions of Python it uses the
+(undocumented) ``PyThread_type_lock``.

comment_data.body:
We do definitely need to be able to query `needs_explicit_construction/destruction` because cdef classes use it to decide whether to generate functions at all.

Given that, I'm not sure if it's worth changing this usage to work without the check? I'm happy to do it though if you think it is.

comment_data.body: I've moved it out to the `CythonLockType` scope. I think it should remain a workaround specific to this class for now. But it definitely doesn't need to be defined in `__init__`

comment_data.body:
I just copied it from `CComplexType`. So there isn't a deeper reason.

I think the three options are:
* do it like this
* do it in `__init__` (always)
* make `scope` a property and and do it there.

I don't really have a strong preference between those.

+    def get_utility_code(self):
+        # It doesn't seem like a good way to associate utility code with a type actually exists
+        # so we just have to do it in as many places as possible.
+        return UtilityCode.load_cached(self.cname_part, "Lock.c")
+
+    def needs_explicit_construction(self, scope):
+        # Where possible we use mutex types that don't require
+        # explicit construction (e.g. PyMutex). However, on older
+        # versions this isn't possible, and we fall back to types
+        # that do need non-static initialization.
+        return True
+
+    def needs_explicit_destruction(self, scope):
+        return True
+
+    def generate_explicit_construction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        code.globalstate.use_utility_code(
+            self.get_utility_code()
+        )
+        code.putln(f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_Init({extra_access_code}{entry.cname});")
+
+    def generate_explicit_destruction(self, code, entry, extra_access_code=""):
+        code.putln(
+            f"__Pyx_Locks_{self.cname_part}_Delete({extra_access_code}{entry.cname});")
+
+    def attributes_known(self):
+        if self.scope is None:
+            from . import Symtab
+
+            self.scope = scope = Symtab.CClassScope(

comment_data.body:
We currently only use this in one place and it's the former. It's to raise an exception, so if we have the GIL then we just raise it, otherwise we need to ensure that we have the GIL.

At one point I was planning to use this class for this PR, and it would have needed to treat all three cases separately. So this class doesn't actually need to change for this PR - it's only being changed because of the new enum type.

So I think it makes sense to leave it as here.

+        return False

comment_data.body:
Not sure that's quite right:

`generate_explicit_destruction` is if we have an instance of something and we need to destroy that instance.

cdef classes need to know whether to generate a `tp_dealloc` function (and if nothing in the class needs to be manually destructed then we don't need `tp_dealloc`). To do that they need to query all their members.

Instances of cdef classes are destroyed by reference counting so no cdef class ever needs `generate_explicit_destruction`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3386,6 +3408,8 @@ def generate_module_cleanup_func(self, env, code):
                             entry_cname, entry.type,
                             clear_before_decref=True,
                             nanny=False)
+                    if entry.type.needs_explicit_destruction(env):
+                        entry.type.generate_explicit_destruction(code, entry)
